searchDocs.title: sidebar_position: 2​
searchDocs.content: Customizing Zymmr

searchDocs.title: Examples of Project Milestones:​
searchDocs.content: Project Kickoff: Initiate the project with a kickoff meeting, outlining project objectives, scope, and roles. This sets the stage for the entire project. Completion of Project Planning: Finalize the project plan, including tasks, timelines, and resource allocation. This milestone ensures that the team is ready to move into the execution phase. Prototype Development: For software or product development projects, completing the prototype is a significant milestone. It allows stakeholders to visualize the end product and provide feedback. User Acceptance Testing (UAT): Successfully completing UAT signifies that the project deliverables meet the user's requirements and expectations. Launch or Go-Live: The official launch or deployment of the project is a major milestone. It marks the completion of the project and the beginning of its operational phase. Client Approval: Obtaining client approval is crucial for projects involving external clients. It indicates that the project has met the client's satisfaction and is ready for closure. Project Review and Lessons Learned: Conducting a project review and documenting lessons learned is a milestone that facilitates continuous improvement for future projects.  [Learn more about using project milestones in zymmr]

searchDocs.title: Key Features of Capacity Planning in Zymmr:​
searchDocs.content: Define Team Member Capacity: Set the capacity for each team member across projects. This allows for a clear understanding of each individual's availability and workload. Overallocation Highlighting: Automatically identify and highlight overallocation of resources. This feature helps in balancing the workload effectively. Capacity Visibility: View the capacity for all team members in one place. This comprehensive overview helps in better planning and management of resources. Filtering Options: Filter capacity information based on various criteria such as User, project, or timeframe. This flexibility allows for targeted analysis and decision-making.

searchDocs.title: Steps for Capacity Planning in Zymmr:​
searchDocs.content: Access Resource Management: Navigate to the Resource Management section in Zymmr from your dashboard. Set Team Member Capacity: Select a team member.Define their capacity for the project(s) by setting the available hours or effort. Monitor Overallocation: Check for any highlighted overallocation in the resource management view.Reallocate tasks or adjust timelines to address overallocation issues. Adjust and Optimize: Based on the capacity data, make necessary adjustments to ensure balanced workloads.Continuously monitor and refine capacity planning to adapt to changes in project scope or team availability.  By utilizing Zymmr's Capacity Planning features, teams can ensure optimal resource utilization, prevent burnout, and enhance overall project efficiency. This proactive approach to capacity management helps in delivering projects on time and within budget.

searchDocs.title: Resource Management
searchDocs.content: Resource Management

searchDocs.title: Key Components of Agile Project Management​
searchDocs.content: Iterative Development: Projects are broken down into small, manageable iterations or sprints.Scrum Framework: Utilizes roles such as Scrum Master and Product Owner, and events like Sprint Planning, Daily Stand-ups, Sprint Review, and Retrospective.Collaborative Approach: Emphasis on teamwork, communication, and collaboration between cross-functional teams.Customer Collaboration: Continuous involvement of stakeholders and customers throughout the project lifecycle.Adaptive Planning: Flexibility to adapt to changing requirements and priorities.Continuous Improvement: Iterative feedback loops to enhance product quality and process efficiency.Transparent Metrics: Metrics like velocity and burn-down charts provide visibility into progress and potential issues.

searchDocs.title: Setting up a Scrum Project​
searchDocs.content: Define Project Vision: Establish clear project goals and objectives.Create Product Backlog in Zymmr: Compile a prioritized list of features, enhancements, and fixes as user stories.Form Scrum Team: Select cross-functional team members, including Scrum Master and Product Owner.Sprint Planning in Zymmr: Plan and prioritize tasks for the upcoming sprint based on the product backlog.Daily Stand-ups: Daily meetings to review progress, discuss obstacles, and plan for the day.Sprint Review: Demonstrate completed work to stakeholders and gather feedback.Sprint Retrospective: Reflect on what went well, what could be improved, and actions for the next sprint.Build Metrics in Zymmr: Utilize Zymmr to create and monitor burn-down and burn-up charts.

searchDocs.title: Navigate to Project Settings​
searchDocs.content: Go to the project listing page where all projects assigned to you are listed.Choose the project by selecting the project.Click on "Project Settings."

searchDocs.title: Assign Permissions​
searchDocs.content: In the Project Settings page, locate the permissions section. The functions are listed on the left and the roles are listed on the right.

searchDocs.title: Add Role to a Function​
searchDocs.content: To add a new role to a function, press the "+" icon next to the desired function.Choose the role you want to assign from the dropdown list.

searchDocs.title: Select Functions​
searchDocs.content: Available functions you can assign roles to include:  Browse ProjectAdminister ProjectCreate Work ItemAdd AttachmentDelete AttachmentAdd CommentEdit CommentDelete CommentView CommentView AttachmentAdd TimelogView TimelogDelete TimelogEdit Work ItemManage SprintDelete Work Item

searchDocs.title: Important Notes​
searchDocs.content: Ensure roles are predefined before attempting to assign permissions.Review the selected functions to ensure the role has the appropriate permissions.

searchDocs.title: Project Listing Page​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the project listing page where all projects assigned to you are listed.Choose the project by selecting the project.

searchDocs.title: Open Project Details​
searchDocs.content: The project details include the following information:  LeadTimelineWork Item Type SchemeWorkflow Scheme

searchDocs.title: Edit Project Settings​
searchDocs.content: Click on "Project Settings."The following fields will be shown for editing: NameStart DateEnd DateDescriptionPermission SchemeStatusCategory

searchDocs.title: Edit Details​
searchDocs.content: Click "Edit Details" to modify the above fields. Note: The project key cannot be edited.

searchDocs.title: Important Notes​
searchDocs.content: Ensure you have the necessary permissions to edit project settings.Review all changes before saving to avoid any misconfigurations.

searchDocs.title: What is a Module?​
searchDocs.content: A module in Zymmr is a logical grouping of related work items or functionalities within a project. It helps in organizing work and managing specific areas of a project more efficiently. Modules allow teams to focus on distinct sections of a project, making tracking and managing different components easier.

searchDocs.title: How to Create a Module in Zymmr​
Navigate to Project Listing Page​
searchDocs.content: From the Projects listing, search for the project you want to configure.Click on the project to open it.On the right side, click on the 'Project Configuration Settings' icon.

searchDocs.title: Access the Module Section​
searchDocs.content: In the configuration settings, look for the Module section.Click on the Module section to open it.

searchDocs.title: Create a Module​
searchDocs.content: Click on the 'Create Module' icon.Fill in the following details: Module Name: Enter a descriptive name for the module.Module Description: Provide a detailed description of the module.Module Lead: Assign a user responsible for the module. Click the 'Save' button to save the details.Once saved, the module and its attributes get listed. Refer to Linking a Module to a Work Item for more details.

searchDocs.title: View and Manage Modules​
searchDocs.content: All modules available for the project will be listed.Against each module, you will see the 'Edit' and 'Delete' icons. Note: If a module is linked to a work item, the module cannot be edited or deleted.

searchDocs.title: Limitation​
searchDocs.content: Currently, they are not visible across the Gantt chart to provide a visual representation of Modules.

searchDocs.title: Key Components of Kanban Project Management​
searchDocs.content: Board in Zymmr: Utilize a Kanban board to visualize the workflow, showing tasks in different stages such as To Do, In Progress, and Done.Continuous Delivery: Focus on delivering small, incremental updates continuously rather than in large batches.Pull System: Team members pull tasks from a backlog or the previous stage when they have capacity, ensuring a balanced workload.Flexible Planning: Adapt to changing priorities and requirements easily, allowing for more flexible and dynamic planning.Continuous Improvement: Regularly review and improve processes through feedback loops and performance metrics.Metrics and Analytics: Use metrics such as cycle time, lead time, and cumulative flow diagrams to gain insights into process efficiency and identify areas for improvement.

searchDocs.title: Setting up a Kanban Project in Zymmr​
searchDocs.content: Create Kanban Board in Zymmr: Set up a visual Kanban board in Zymmr with columns representing different stages of the workflow.Add Work Items: Populate the Kanban board with tasks, representing each as a card that moves through stages.Prioritize Tasks: Continuously prioritize tasks based on business value, urgency, and team capacity.Daily Stand-ups: Hold daily meetings to review progress, discuss challenges, and coordinate efforts.Monitor Flow: Regularly track and analyze the flow of tasks using Zymmr’s built-in metrics and analytics.Review and Adapt: Conduct periodic reviews to identify bottlenecks, gather feedback, and implement improvements.

searchDocs.title: Utilizing Kanban Metrics in Zymmr​
searchDocs.content: Cycle Time: Measure the time taken for a task to move from start to completion.Lead Time: Track the total time from when a task is requested to when it is delivered.Cumulative Flow Diagram: Visualize the number of tasks in each stage over time to identify bottlenecks and workflow efficiency.Throughput: Measure the number of tasks completed in a given time period to gauge team productivity.  By following these steps, you can effectively set up and manage a Kanban project in Zymmr, ensuring a streamlined and efficient workflow.

searchDocs.title: Sprint
searchDocs.content: Sprint

searchDocs.title: Timesheet
searchDocs.content: Timesheet

searchDocs.title: What is a Milestone?​
searchDocs.content: A milestone is a significant event or a marker in a project timeline that signifies the completion of a major phase or work item. In Zymmr, milestones are defined at a project level and help in tracking progress, ensuring that the project is on schedule. They can be associated with specific work items.

searchDocs.title: How to Create a Milestone in Zymmr​
Navigate to Project Configuration Settings​
searchDocs.content: From the Projects listing, search for the project you want to configure.Click on the project to open it.On the right side, click on the 'Project Configuration Settings' icon.

searchDocs.title: Choose Milestone​
searchDocs.content: In the configuration settings, look for the Milestone section. The icon is represented by four horizontal lines.Click on the Milestone section to open it.

searchDocs.title: Create a Milestone​
searchDocs.content: Click on the 'Create Milestone' icon.Fill in the following details: Milestone Name: Enter a descriptive name for the milestone.Milestone Type: Select the type of milestone (Engineering or Billing).Owner: Assign a user responsible for the milestone.Status: Set the status of the milestone (In Progress, Completed).From Date: Define the start date of the milestone.To Date: Define the end date of the milestone. Click 'Save' to create the milestone.

searchDocs.title: How to Search and Edit a Milestone​
Search for a Milestone​
searchDocs.content: In the Milestone section of the Project Configuration Settings, use the search bar to find the milestone you want to edit.

searchDocs.title: Edit Milestone Details​
searchDocs.content: Click on the milestone from the search results.Update the necessary details such as Milestone Name, Type, Owner, Status, From Date, and To Date.Click 'Save' to apply the changes.

searchDocs.title: Search for the Milestone​
searchDocs.content: Use the search function in the Milestone section to find the milestone you wish to delete.

searchDocs.title: Delete the Milestone​
searchDocs.content: Select the milestone from the search results.Click on the 'Delete' icon.Confirm the deletion when prompted.  By following these steps, you can effectively manage milestones in Zymmr, ensuring that your project timelines are well-organized and transparent.

searchDocs.title: Limitation​
searchDocs.content: Currently, milestones are not visible across the Gantt chart to provide a clear visual representation of project timelines.

searchDocs.title: Navigate to Project Settings​
searchDocs.content: Go to the project listing page where all projects assigned to you are listed.Choose the project by selecting the project.Click on "Project Settings."

searchDocs.title: Add Members​
searchDocs.content: In the Project Settings page, choose the icon labeled "People" to add members to the project.Select the desired role from the dropdown list.Then, select the user from the dropdown list. Note: Both Role and User should be predefined. Refer to the documentation for Create Roles and Create Users in the settings for more information.

searchDocs.title: Important Notes​
searchDocs.content: Ensure roles and users are predefined before attempting to add members to a project.Review the selected role and user to ensure correct assignments.

searchDocs.title: Key Features​
searchDocs.content: Table Format: Tasks are displayed in a table with the following columns: TitleStatusProgress (%)Start DateEnd DateTags Example: Detailed Overview: This layout offers a detailed overview of each task's status and timeline, facilitating effective project management. Gantt-like Order: Tasks are ordered chronologically, similar to how they would appear in a traditional Gantt chart. This sequential arrangement helps in understanding task dependencies and project progression. Filters: Filters can be applied to customize the view based on criteria such as task status, tags, or assigned team members. This flexibility allows users to focus on specific aspects of the project or team responsibilities.

searchDocs.title: Using Roadmaps​
searchDocs.content: Navigating the Table: Scroll horizontally and vertically to view different tasks and their details. Adjust the zoom or view settings to fit more tasks or focus on specific timeframes. Collaboration: Roadmaps facilitate collaboration by providing a centralized view of project plans. Team members can comment, attach files, or mention others to discuss specific tasks or milestones. Export and Integration: Export roadmaps to share with stakeholders or integrate with other tools for comprehensive project management.

searchDocs.title: Conclusion​
searchDocs.content: Zymmr's roadmap feature combines the clarity of a Gantt chart with the flexibility of table-based task management. It empowers teams to plan effectively, track progress, and adapt to changing project needs.

searchDocs.content: Reports and Dashboard

searchDocs.title: Windows​
searchDocs.content: Install Docker Desktop: If you haven't already, you need to install Docker Desktop on your Windows machine. Docker Desktop provides an easy-to-use interface for managing Docker containers and images on Windows. You can download it from the official Docker website and follow the installation instructions. Clone this repo or download the compose file: This file will define the configuration for your Docker containers, including the environment variables, services, networks, and volumes. Open Command Prompt or PowerShell: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell on your Windows machine. Navigate to Project Directory: Use the cd command to navigate to the directory where your docker-compose.yml file is located. Run Docker Compose Command: Once you're in the correct directory, you can run the following command to start the containers defined in your docker-compose.yml file: set SITE_NAME=abc.zymmr.com && docker-compose up -d This command sets the SITE_NAME environment variable to abc.zymmr.com and then starts the Docker containers defined in the docker-compose.yml file in detached mode (-d flag). Once the containers are up and running, you can verify that everything is working as expected. You can access Zymmmr by opening a web browser and navigating to http://<server-ip>

searchDocs.title: Linux​
searchDocs.content: Install Docker Engine: If you haven't already, you need to install Docker Engine on your Linux machine. Docker Engine provides a platform to develop, ship, and run containers. You can install it by following the official Docker documentation for your specific Linux distribution. Clone this repo or download the compose file: This file will define the configuration for your Docker containers, including the environment variables, services, networks, and volumes. Open Terminal: Open a terminal on your Linux machine. Navigate to Project Directory: Use the cd command to navigate to the directory where your docker-compose.yml file is located. Run Docker Compose Command: Once you're in the correct directory, you can run the following command to start the containers defined in your docker-compose.yml file: SITE_NAME=abc.zymmr.com && docker-compose up -d This command sets the SITE_NAME environment variable to abc.zymmr.com and then starts the Docker containers defined in the docker-compose.yml file in detached mode (-d flag). Once the containers are up and running, you can verify that everything is working as expected. You can access your Zymmr by opening a web browser and navigating to http://<server-ip>

searchDocs.title: So what is a Zymmr project?​
searchDocs.content: A project is a container that groups different workItems together. This group of workItems could cover either a single day’s work or task that will take your team months to complete.  Now we have read about project is all about group of workItems, so what these workItems are?  WorkItem is typically a unit of work, task, bug report, user story, or any other trackable item that represents a piece of work to be completed or managed within a project. workItems are at the core of Zymmr's project management and workItem tracking capabilities.  They help teams plan, track, collaborate, and report on work items throughout the project lifecycle.

searchDocs.title: Accessing Project in Zymmr​
searchDocs.content: Accessing Projects: After logging in as an end user, you will be taken to projects pageIf you are not on project page then you can find your projects in the top navigation bar.Click on the "Projects" tab to see a list of available projects.You can also scroll through the list or use the search function to find a specific project. Navigating to a Project: Once you've found the project you want to work on, click on it.This action will take you to the project's backlog page.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0PlOK9DlTUo

searchDocs.title: Working On WorkItems in Zymmr​
searchDocs.content: In Zymmr, there are various ways to access work items. For instance, you can find them in the project backlog list, which is available for both Kanban and Scrum projects.  If you're working on a Scrum project, you might also have work items within sprints. Additionally, you have the option to perform a direct search from the top navigation bar.  After you've identified the specific work item you want to focus on, simply click on its work item key, and this action will open up the detailed work item page.

searchDocs.title: Updating fields​
searchDocs.content: In Zymmr, users have the flexibility to update work item fields directly, which means that any changes made to a field's value will automatically save that specific field without the need for manual saving.  Zymmr offers more than 32 standard fields which covers almost any use-case for managing projects which mainly includes assignments, Estimates, Timelines, WorkItem Tracking and others to capture essential information    Explore each field in detail here

searchDocs.title: Adding comment​
searchDocs.content: Comments are simple text based updates to let team know what's happening on the WorkItem  tip Comment supports mentioning teammates so if you want someone to know about a comment, you can mention them in it. Type @ followed by their name, then choose the right person from the list. The person you mention will be notified about your comment and can quickly jump to the WorkItem to see the updates.  Here how you can add comment on Zymmr WorkItem  Begin by opening the work item.Locate the comments tab at the bottom of the screen.Type your comment in the provided field.Finally, click on the "Post" button to submit your comment.

searchDocs.title: Adding WorkLog to WorkItem​
searchDocs.content: Go to the specific WorkItem you want to add a workog for.click on the "More" option, ****Located at the top-right corner of the WorkItem.From the dropdown menu that appears when you click "More," select Add Time LogIn the "Add Time Log" dialog box, provide the following information: Work Type: Select the type of work forex: Development, Testing, Meetting, R&D etc.Date Started: Select the date and time when you started working on the WorkItem.Time Spent: Enter the amount of time you've spent on the WorkItemComment: Add any comments or notes regarding your work. Once you've filled in the necessary information, click the Add button to save the worklog.  Your worklog is now added to the WorkItem, and it will display the date, time spent, and any comments you provided. This helps in tracking and documenting work performed on the WorkItem in Zymmr.

searchDocs.title: WorkItem workflow in Zymmr​
searchDocs.content: Workflow is like a recipe that guides you through the steps to get something done  In Zymmr, Workflows of any WorkItem is managed through states and actions aka transitions  At the very minimum, you will have a Work Item that goes through 3-4 states, such as New, In Progress, Done, and, in some cases, On Hold.    Where can I see this guided states in zymmr WorkItem?  In the Zymmr WorkItem context, we refer to this field as 'Status,' where you will be shown the next states along the transition it go through.

searchDocs.title: WorkItem in Zymmr: A Comprehensive Guide
Key Attributes of WorkItem​
searchDocs.pageTitle: WorkItem in Zymmr: A Comprehensive Guide
searchDocs.content: Title: A concise label for the WorkItem that succinctly conveys its purpose. Description: A detailed narrative outlining the scope, objectives, and requirements of the WorkItem. WorkItem Key: A unique identifier assigned to each individual WorkItem. Project Name: A unique and descriptive title for the specific project. WorkItem Type: Categorization or classification of a work item, such as tasks, bugs, or user stories. WorkItem Priority: Relative importance or urgency assigned to a specific task within a project. WorkItem Status: Current state or condition of a specific task, indicating whether it's complete, in progress, or facing challenges. Primary Assignee: The person primarily responsible for completing a specific WorkItem. Secondary Assignee: An individual providing additional support or assistance for a specific WorkItem. Reporter: The person who raises or creates a WorkItem within Zymmr. Story Points: A unit of measurement used in Agile methodologies to estimate the effort and complexity of tasks. Estimate Effort: Expected amount of time required to complete a specific WorkItem. Logged Time: Actual time spent working on a specific WorkItem. Remaining Time: Time needed to complete a task based on the initial estimate and logged time. Auto Estimate: Machine learning feature predicting and assigning estimated effort or time to WorkItem. Start Date: Planned date when the task is scheduled to begin. End Date: Planned date when the task is expected to complete. Watchers: Individuals interested in staying updated about the progress and changes related to a specific issue. Tags: Labels or keywords associated with WorkItems for categorization and organization. Parent WorkItem: Higher-level task or issue that encompasses related sub-tasks or child issues. Affects Versions: Indicates which versions or releases of a product are impacted by a specific issue. Fix Version: Indicates in which version or release an issue has been resolved or fixed. Modules: Labels or categories used to group and categorize WorkItems within a project. Milestone: Significant event or achievement marking a specific point in a project's timeline. Comments: Text-based messages or notes added to issues for communication and collaboration. Attachments: Files, documents, or images associated with a specific WorkItem. Related Task: Establishes relationships or connections between different WorkItems within a project. Activity Log: Records all activities, changes, and events throughout the lifecycle of a WorkItem. Time Log: Recording the time spent on specific WorkItems within a project. Sprint: Represents the Agile concept of a fixed time period during which a team works on a set of tasks. Dev Tab: Provides insights into the technical development and coding aspects of a WorkItem. Bitbucket Integration: Seamless workflow for tracking and managing development activities, code changes, and project progress.

searchDocs.title: From the top navigation bar, anywhere in Zymmr​
What is a Release?​
searchDocs.content: A release in Zymmr is a specific version or segment of a project that is delivered to stakeholders. Releases help manage and track project deliverables, ensuring each version is documented and delivered on schedule.

searchDocs.title: How to Create a Release in Zymmr​
Navigate to Project Listing Page​
searchDocs.content: From the Projects listing, search for the project you want to configure.Click on the project to open it.On the right side, click on the 'Project Configuration Settings' icon.

searchDocs.title: Access the Releases Section​
searchDocs.content: In the configuration settings, look for the Releases section.Click on the Releases section to open it.

searchDocs.title: Create a Release​
searchDocs.content: Click on the 'Create Release' icon.Fill in the following details: Release Name: Enter a descriptive name for the release.Start Date: Define the start date of the release.End Date: Define the end date of the release.Description: Provide a detailed description of the release. Click the 'Save' button to save the details.Once saved, all releases are listed.

searchDocs.title: View and Manage Releases​
searchDocs.content: All releases for the project will be listed with the following information:  Release NameStart DateEnd DateStatus: Shows if the release is unreleased or has been released.

searchDocs.title: Options available for each release include:​
searchDocs.content: Release: Release this changing the status to ‘Released’ Archive: Archive the release. Edit: Edit the release details. Delete: Delete the release. Note: All releases are considered unreleased until the status is changed to "Released." The release listing also includes a search function to find specific releases. Note: If a work item is associated with a release, the release cannot be deleted. An error message will indicate this restriction.

searchDocs.title: How to Search and Edit a Release​
Search for a Release​
searchDocs.content: Use the search function in the Releases section to find the release you want to edit.

searchDocs.title: Edit Release Details​
searchDocs.content: Click on the 'Edit' icon in the options next to the release you want to modify.Update the necessary details such as Release Name, Start Date, End Date, and Description.Click 'Save' to apply the changes.

searchDocs.title: Search for the Release​
searchDocs.content: Use the search function in the Releases section to find the release you wish to delete.

searchDocs.title: Delete the Release​
searchDocs.content: Click on the 'Delete' icon next to the release.Confirm the deletion when prompted. Note: If a work item is associated with a release, the release cannot be deleted. An error message will indicate this restriction.

searchDocs.title: Important Note​
searchDocs.content: Releases will remain in the "unreleased" state until the status is explicitly changed to "released," impacting the project's tracking and reporting.

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: Project management is a systematic approach to planning, executing, and completing a project within a set timeframe and budget. It involves coordinating various tasks, resources, and stakeholders to achieve specific objectives. In the context of product development, effective project management is crucial for ensuring that the product is delivered successfully, meeting quality standards and customer expectations.

searchDocs.title: Key Components of Project Management​
searchDocs.content: Initiation: This phase involves defining the project, its purpose, and the scope of work. Identifying key stakeholders and understanding their expectations is crucial at this stage. Planning: Project planning involves creating a detailed roadmap that outlines tasks, timelines, and resource requirements. This phase helps in establishing realistic goals and allocating resources efficiently. Execution: The actual work of the project takes place in this phase. Project managers and team members collaborate to complete tasks, and communication becomes paramount to ensure everyone is on the same page. Monitoring and Controlling: Progress is monitored regularly, and adjustments are made to keep the project on track. This phase involves identifying and addressing issues, risks, and changes as they arise. Closing: After completing all project deliverables and obtaining necessary approvals, the project is closed. This includes a final evaluation to ensure all objectives were met.

searchDocs.title: Types of Project Management​
searchDocs.content: Waterfall Methodology: This traditional approach follows a linear sequence, where each phase must be completed before moving on to the next. It's suitable for well-defined projects with minimal changes expected. Agile Methodology: Agile is an iterative approach that emphasizes flexibility and responsiveness to change. It breaks the project into small increments, allowing for adjustments based on feedback throughout the development process. Scrum: A subset of Agile, Scrum divides the project into fixed-length iterations called sprints. It promotes collaboration, adaptability, and continuous improvement. Kanban: Originating from lean manufacturing, Kanban focuses on visualizing the workflow. Tasks move through different stages on a board, providing a real-time view of progress. Critical Path Method (CPM): CPM identifies the longest sequence of dependent tasks to determine the minimum time needed to complete a project. It's particularly useful for projects with a strict timeline.  tip Effective project management is essential for better project deliveries, ensuring that goals are achieved efficiently. Choosing the right project management methodology depends on the nature of the project, the level of flexibility required, and the team's preferences and capabilities.and all this can be easily achieved in zymmr  did you know ? The "90-90" rule humorously states that the first 90% of a project takes 90% of the time, and the last 10% also takes 90% of the time. It playfully reflects the challenges often faced in completing the final stages of a project, where unforeseen issues and complexities may arise.

See How   warning You are not allowed to delete category if its assigned on any project,To delete you need to either re-assign or remove category from project

searchDocs.title: Create an Issue Type Scheme:​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the Administration section in Zymmr.Find and select the "Work Item Type Schemes" option.Create a new scheme named "Software Project Types" or a relevant title.

searchDocs.title: Define Work Item Types:​
searchDocs.content: Add the necessary issue types for your software project. In this example, include: BugFeature  Check how to create new work item here

searchDocs.title: Configure the Work Item Type Scheme:​
searchDocs.content: Associate the created issue types with the scheme. Bug -> BugFeature -> Feature

searchDocs.title: Set Default Issue Type:​
searchDocs.content: Choose a default issue type for your scheme. For instance, set "Bug" as the default type.

searchDocs.title: Apply the Scheme to Projects:​
searchDocs.content: Once configured, apply the "Software Project Types" scheme to relevant software projects.This ensures that these projects share a standardized set of issue types.  By implementing this work item type scheme, your team can easily select appropriate issue types when creating new items. It also ensures consistency across projects, making it more straightforward to manage and maintain your projects within Zymmr.

searchDocs.title: User
searchDocs.content: User

searchDocs.title: Project Settings
searchDocs.content: Project Settings

searchDocs.title: Defining Milestones​
searchDocs.content: Project Level Definition: Milestones are created and managed at the project level, ensuring they are aligned with the overall project goals and timelines.Identification: Each milestone is identified with a unique name to distinguish it from other milestones within the project.Milestone Type: Milestones can be categorized as either engineering milestones, which pertain to technical deliverables, or billing milestones, which are related to financial or invoicing checkpoints.Responsibility Assignment: A specific user is assigned responsibility for each milestone, ensuring accountability and clear ownership of milestone tasks.Start and End Dates: Each milestone is associated with a defined start and end date, providing a clear timeframe for completion.

searchDocs.title: Utilizing Milestones​
searchDocs.content: Integration with Gantt Chart: Milestones are visible across all tasks in the Gantt chart, offering a comprehensive view of project timelines and critical checkpoints.Tracking Progress: By integrating milestones into the Gantt chart, project managers can easily track progress against these key targets, ensuring that tasks are completed on schedule.Enhanced Project Management: The clear definition and tracking of milestones help in better planning, execution, and monitoring of projects, facilitating timely adjustments and proactive management.

searchDocs.title: Example Use Cases​
searchDocs.content: Engineering Milestones: These might include the completion of design phases, code development, testing stages, and deployment.Billing Milestones: These could involve client invoicing stages, payment schedules, and financial approvals.  By incorporating milestones into your project management process with Zymmr, you gain better control and visibility over your project's critical phases, enhancing overall project efficiency and success.

searchDocs.title: Default Issue Types​
searchDocs.content: Here's a list of the default work item types that come with each Zymmer project:

searchDocs.title: Epic​
searchDocs.content: An Epic is like a big story for your project that's too large to handle all at once. It's made up of bugs, stories, and tasks, showing how things are progressing with a major project. In agile development, epics usually stand for something big, like a cool new feature or experience in the software your team is building.

searchDocs.title: Bug​
searchDocs.content: A bug is a problem that messes up or stops a product from working properly.

searchDocs.title: Story​
searchDocs.content: A user story is the smallest piece of work that needs to get done.

searchDocs.title: Task​
searchDocs.content: A task is a job that needs to be finished.

searchDocs.title: Subtask​
searchDocs.content: A subtask is a small piece of work needed to finish a task. Subtasks can break down any regular jobs in Zymmr, like bugs, stories, or tasks.  Each project in Zymmer comes with default work item types carefully crafted to meet the diverse needs of your projects and teams. Yet, we understand that one size doesn't fit all. That's why Zymmr allows you to tailor your work item types to align seamlessly with your preferred project management process.

searchDocs.title: Using WorkItem in Project​
searchDocs.content: note You need to be Global Admin or Account admin to Manage workitems
